title: 104_hr1093
content:
Section 9(a)(1) of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to authorize the Secretary to establish specific time periods for retailers to accept and redeem food stamps. Additionally, regulations can be issued to prohibit stores from participating in the program based on lack of business integrity. The Secretary is authorized to establish time periods for retailers with denied or withdrawn approval to reapply based on business integrity. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include requirements for submitting relevant income and tax documents for eligibility verification. Retail food stores may need to provide authorization for tax filings verification. Additionally, there is a waiting period for stores that initially fail to meet authorization criteria. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include a provision that prohibits retail food stores or wholesale food concerns from reapplying for approval to accept and redeem coupons for six months if their initial application is denied due to not meeting criteria set by the Secretary. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 now includes criteria for suspensions and disqualifications of retail food stores or wholesale food concerns based on evidence like on-site investigations or inconsistent redemption data. Additionally, stores violating program requirements can be suspended pending administrative and judicial review. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 allows for the suspension of retail food stores or wholesale food concerns found violating program requirements. Suspensions may coincide with review periods, and the Secretary is not liable for any lost sales during suspension or disqualification. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 allows for the suspension of retail food stores or wholesale food concerns for violations. Suspensions remain in effect during reviews, and the period of suspension counts towards any disqualification imposed. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 allows for the disqualification of retailers who are disqualified from the WIC program. The Secretary will issue regulations for disqualification criteria, with the disqualification period matching that of the WIC Program. Additionally, retailers who intentionally submit falsified applications face permanent debarment. Expanded civil and criminal forfeiture for violations of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 includes permanent disqualification of retail food stores or wholesale food concerns found to have knowingly submitted false information in their application to accept and redeem coupons. Disqualification remains in effect pending administrative and judicial review. Sec. 109 amends the Food Stamp Act of 1977 to include civil forfeiture for violations involving food stamp benefits valued at $5,000 or more. Civil forfeiture provisions under chapter 46 of title 18 apply to seizures or forfeitures related to violations of the Food Stamp Act involving benefits worth $5,000 or more. Offenders must forfeit any benefits, property, or proceeds obtained from the violation to the United States. The Food Stamp Act mandates that individuals involved in violations worth $5,000 or more must forfeit any food stamp benefits and related property to the United States. The forfeiture process is governed by specific provisions outlined in the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970. The Secretary may prescribe rules and regulations to carry out this subsection, which does not apply to property specified in subsection (g). Expanded authority for sharing information provided by retailers. Expanded authority for sharing information provided by retailers regarding the Social Security Act and State government officers and agencies responsible for administering the WIC program. Expanded authority for sharing information by retailers under the Social Security Act and State government officers and agencies responsible for administering the WIC program is amended to include State government officers and employees with law enforcement or investigative responsibilities, as well as State agencies administering the WIC program. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include various forms of authorization cards, cash, checks, and access devices like electronic benefit transfer cards. Penalties for violating program requirements have been increased, with penalties now doubled for certain violations. Mandatory claims collection methods are also established. Sec. 202 of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to include refunds of Federal taxes authorized by 31 U.S.C. 3720A. Section 13(d) is also amended to change "may" to "shall" and include refunds of Federal taxes. Additionally, Section 6103(1) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include State agencies as authorized agents. The provisions of this section, effective October 1, 1995, involve amending the Food Stamp Act of 1977 to include refunds of Federal taxes and changing "may" to "shall" for refunds. Additionally, State agencies are included as authorized agents in the Internal Revenue Code. TITLE III--IMPLEMENTATION AND EFFECTIVE DATES

Sec. 301. The provisions of this Act shall become effective and be implemented on the date of enactment.
